artist: Engraver: Cornelis Bloemaert; After Abraham Bloemaert
inscription:
Signature, and Inscription

in plate below image in black: [O fælix, quæ Virgo graris(?), gremiogé cubantem/ Foues Dwum dulciqé lactas vbere!/ Scandere te dignam mubes et cornua Lunæ/ Ludant Cherubim, colitgé Sol et Sydera/ A. Bloemaert/ Inventor(left of inscription)   (right of inscription)C. Bloem:Sculp:/et excud:A 102 5(in pencil)]; on mount lower right in pencil: [H 9 A B/ H (7)n C B]
life_date: Cornelis Bloemaert, Engraver, Dutch, 1603–1684; After Abraham Bloemaert, Dutch, 1566–1651
text: For many decades, Abraham Bloemaert was the leading Catholic painter in the Dutch Republic. His was a family business, with his son Cornelis making prints based on Abraham’s designs. Catholicism was tolerated by the Protestant majority, but Catholics had to hide their churches behind discreet façades; their devotion had to be private. Bloemaert’s star-studded recasting of Federico Barocci’s heavenly Virgin could be used for private devotion in the home.
title: Madonna and Child in the Clouds
